captions.text: [music]
It's almost Christmas time in Korea so we're starting to decorate,
and our theme is with blue.  I have blue balls!
Wait.
That didn't sound right.
Simon, can we do that over?
[music]
So, what's Christmas like in Korea?  Well, the biggest difference is definitely the food.
Yes.  There are a lot of foods that we're used to for Christmas time
and those are gonna be difficult to find here, for example:
if you want a turkey, it's gonna be not only difficult to find, but very expensive as well if you do find one.
If you are coming to Korea for Christmas time, or if you have friends in Korea,
we recommend sending them a simple care package, like, for example,
cranberry sauce, stuffing mix, pre-made gravy mix, candy canes.
Oh yeah!  You can get them, but they're kinda hard to find.
Minty things, or Christmas cookies, that kinda stuff.
That can really make you feel comforted when you're in Korea.
Other than that, you're on your own, and you're gonna have to make the food yourself.
That's right: egg nog, hot apple cider, cheese potato gratin,
I'm all makin it!
Ok so currently I'm starting to make egg-nog.
There's no eggnog in Korea.  I cannot find it anywhere in all of Korea.
so I have to make it from scratch.  Yay eggnog!
[music]
So, one thing you will find in Korea is the Christmas spirit.
It's not as all-encompassing as it was when we lived in Canada,
but it's definitely here.
And it's definitely growing as well.  This year there are a lot more Christmas lights and carols
than there were last year and the year before that,
so it seems that the Christmas spirit is really starting to get infused into Korean culture.
[music]
So the biggest difference about Christmas in Korea is the actual feeling of the day.
So Christmas Eve is actually a couple's day, it's not really for family.
So, for example, supposedly tonight GD&TOP are going out to Hongdae to different bars and partying,
and partying instead of staying home with their families and having turkey and stuffing
Simon, can I go?
No, you gotta be in the kitchen.  Make me some food!  AHHH!
So, Merry Christmas from Eat Your Kimchi.  Happy Birthday Jesus!
Enjoy your time off with your family and friends.
I, however, am gonna go to the kitchen and make egg-nog for the next three hours.
Cuz they don't have egg-nog in Korea.  What a sin!
I know.  I want egg-nog lattes!  So we're gonna make em.  Merry Christmas!
[music]
